'''Dionisio Gutierrez'''{{Cite web|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/|title=Dionisio Gutiérrez|last=Gutiérrez|first=Dionisio|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} '''(Guatemala, July 23rd, 1959)''' is a Guatemalan businessman, communicator and member of the Board of Directors of Corporación MultiInversiones (CMI){{Cite web|url=https://www.cmi.co/es/|title=CMI|last=Corporación|first=Multi Inversiones|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. He is also the President of Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo{{Cite web|url=https://www.fundacionlibertad.com/|title=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} {{Infobox person | name = Businessman | image = Dionisio Gutiérrez Mayorga Biografía Guatemala.jpg | caption = Dionisio Gutiérrez | native_name = Dionisio Gutiérrez Mayorga | birth_date = July 23, 1959 (59 years old) | birth_place = [[Guatemala city]] | nationality = [[Guatemala]]n | alma mater = [[Pontifical University of Salamanca]] | education = Doctor in Sociology and Political Science | occupation = Businessman, communicator | years_active = 1979 - present | parents = Dionisio Gutiérrez (father), Esperanza Mayorga | relatives = Juan Bautista Gutiérrez (grandfather) | awards = Order of Civil Merit granted by King Felipe VI of Spain (2014). Prize "Empowering Democracy" awarded by Power Awards (2012). | television = Canal 3, Guatevision, Canal Antigua, Emisoras Unidas (radio) | notable_works = Libre Encuentro, Dimensión, Razón de Estado | website = [http://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt www.dionisiogutierrez.gt] }} ==Early Years and Family== Dionisio Gutierrez is the second son of Dionisio Gutierrez and Esperanza Mayorga{{Cite web|url=https://wikiguate.com.gt/juan-bautista-gutierrez-blanco/|title=Juan Bautista Gutiérrez|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. His grandfather, Juan Bautista Gutierrez, was a Spaniard businessman and [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]] who established in [[Guatemala]] in the first years of the 20th Century. He was one of the founders of Multi Inversiones, S. A. According to Francisco Pérez de Antón{{Cite web|url=https://wikiguate.com.gt/francisco-perez-de-anton/|title=Wikiguate Francisco Pérez de Antón|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, “…for Mr. Juan Gutierrez, life had only two purposes: to work and to create a heritage for his descendants{{Cite book|title=Memorial de cocinas y batallas.|last=Pérez de Antón,|first=Francisco|publisher=Penguin Random House Grupo Editorial México|year=2012|isbn=|location=https://books.google.com/books/about/Memorial_de_Cocinas_y_Batallas.html?id=uREWrSqMQWMC|pages=}}” which led him to build “one of the most solid and solvent groups in [[Central America]]”{{Cite book|title=Memorial de cocinas y batallas|last=Pérez de Antón|first=Francisco|publisher=Penguin Random House Grupo Editorial México, 2012.|year=2012|isbn=9929576584|location=https://books.google.com/books/about/Memorial_de_Cocinas_y_Batallas.html?id=uREWrSqMQWMC|pages=113}}. In the decade of the 20’s, Juan Bautista Gutierrez opened a small store in San Cristobal Totonicapan, a small town in the western region of Guatemala. In 1936 he founded Molino Excelsior; in 1965 he started operations in the poultry industry with the Villalobos farm. In the decade of the 70’s, by initiative of his son, Dionisio Gutierrez (father) and Francisco Pérez de Antón, he started in the business of fried chicken, with what would become the most emblematic company of the then Grupo Gutierrez (today, Corporación Multi Inversiones): Pollo Campero. Today, Corporación Multi Inversiones has diversified into different industries: food, livestock, energy, finance, real estate development, telecommunications, among others, adapting to both local and international market trends. === Family Tragedy === On October 3, 1974, the Gutierrez family suffered a painful and sad tragedy, when the small plane bound to Honduras, filled with medicine that had been collected by the Guatemalan Rotary Club for the victims of hurricane Fifi, and piloted by Dionisio Gutierrez father and Alfonso Bosch, plummeted in the midst of San Jose Pinula{{Cite book|title=Memorial de cocinas y batallas|last=Pérez de Antón|first=Francisco|publisher=Penguin Random House Grupo Editorial México|year=2012|isbn=9929576584|location=https://books.google.com.gt/books/about/Memorial%20de%20Cocinas%20y%20Batallas.html?id=uREWrSqMQWMC&redir_esc=y|pages=105-106}}, causing the death of them both. According to Francisco Perez de Antón, that tragedy led to a “generational void” inside the Gutierrez family, since the sons of both Dionisio Gutierrez father and this business partner Alfonso Bosch, were too young to take on management roles in the family business. This is why Dionisio Gutierrez began to work in Grupo Gutierrez since 1976, when he was only 17 years old. Besides, those years were socially and politically convulsive; violence from the local armed conflict and the consolidation of military governments, scourged practically all the Central American region. ==Business career== By the end of the 70’s, Dionisio Gutierrez and his cousin Juan Luis Bosch took on a shared Chief Executive Officer role at Corporación Multi Inversiones{{Cite web|url=https://www.cmi.co/es/quienes-somos/historia|title=Coporación Multi Inversiones|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, a family owned multinational corporation with over 45,000 employees, and presence in 14 countries in three continents. For 33 years, Dionisio Gutierrez held the presidency role in the multinational company, founded by his grandfather in 1936. Currently, he is member of the Management Board at CMI. He has also been Director of the Guatemalan Manager’s Association (Asociación de Gerentes de Guatemala), Director of the Trade Chamber, Director of Banco Occidente, and Vicepresident of Banco Reformador. ==Civic career== His foray into politics starts in the sunset of the military regime, and the beginnings of the democratic era, towards the end of the 80’s. Therefore, for almost forty years, Dionisio Gutierrez has had a permanent participation in the critical moments of the Central American region. === First incursions in the civic scene === Since his college years, Dionisio Gutierrez got involved in projects of several student associations and groups, where he denounced both the actions of the military government and the Marxist guerrilla. Among them Electorama 82,{{Cite web|url=http://fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/biografia|title=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} which was an effort by young people to audit the questioned electoral process of March 7, 1982. A few weeks later, on March 23, General Efraín Ríos-Montt came to power through a coup d’état to the then president Fernando Lucas García{{Cite book|title=Breve historia contemporánea de Guatemala|last=Luján Muñoz|first=Jorge|publisher=Fondo de Cultura Económica|year=|isbn=9681666070|location=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZPZqAAAAMAAJ&q=breve+historia+contempor%C3%A1nea+de+guatemala&dq=breve+historia+contempor%C3%A1nea+de+guatemala&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjkl8a9k_XcAhVJ0FkKHYlxCDkQ6AEIKDAA|pages=}}. Gutierrez also participated with the “Student Committee Against Terrorism” and the “Civil Student Front”, with several publications in the independent journal El Imparcial{{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/hemeroteca/el-recordado-diario-el-imparcial|title=Surge El Imparcial|last=Prensa Libre|first=Guatemala|date=|work=|access-date=}} In 1983, when he was only 24 years old, takes on a role as a member of the board of the Guatemalan Trade Chamber. === Free Enterprise Chamber === For seven years he was president of the Free Enterprise Chamber and led one of the first programs of political surveys in the country. The first publication “Guatemala Responde 1987”{{Cite news|url=http://www.biblioteca.ufm.edu/library/index.php?&title=Special:GSMSearchPage&process=&field1=encabezamiento&value1=DEMOCRACIA%20GUATEMALA%20HISTORIA%20&mode=advanced&page=1|title=Cámara de la Libre Empresa|last=|date=1989|work=|access-date=}} (Guatemala Answers 1987) revealed Guatemalan citizen’s opinion about the economic, political and social situation in the first years of Vinicio Cerezo. Later, in 1989, he published a second edition “Guatemala Responde IV: Percepciones y opiniones del pueblo guatemalteco después de 37 meses de gobierno democrático” and in 1990, he issues a political{{Cite web|url=http://fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/biografia?gclid=EAIaIQobChMImZbk__m13QIVwmSGCh3nLwY0EAAYASABEgLH2_D_BwE|title=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} survey about the voter’s preferences on the presidential elections of that year. === Libre Encuentro === This was a TV show hosted by Dionisio Gutierrez broadcast in Guatemala, other cities in Central America and the United States during twenty years. Libre Encuentro {{Cite web|url=http://www.fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/libre-encuentro|title=Libre Encuentro|last=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}encouraged thought and debate among leaders from different sectors of the society, and became a referent for the public opinion in Guatemala, where he reached record rating levels. In his emissions, Gutierrez stirred debate and controversy among guests from all social sectors and experts. In many occasions even abandoning his role as moderator, and participating in the arguments{{Cite news|url=|title="Insoportable Prepotencia"|last=Zarco|first=José Eduardo|date=|work=Prensa Libre, 5/28/2006|access-date=}}. === Serranazo === Six days after the rupture of the constitutional order perpetrated on Tuesday, May 25, 1993, by Jorge Antonio Serrano Elías{{Cite web|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/un-escenario-politico-similar|title=El Serranazo|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, in which he tried to dissolve the Congress, dismiss the Supreme Court of Justice, the Constitutional Court and the Human Rights Delegate{{Cite book|title=Serranazo|last=Luján Muñoz|first=Jorge|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=385}}. Several Guatemalan civil citizens, among whom was Dionisio Gutiérrez, issued a declaration "Given the political crisis the country is undergoing", better known as the document of "Los Abajo Firmantes"{{Cite news|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/los-abajo-firmantes/|title=Los Abajo Firmantes|last=Prensa Libre|first=Guatemala|date=|work=|access-date=}}, where they rejected the violations of the Constitution by Serrano Elías, calling him "dictator" and demanding his irrevocable resignation as well as the restitution of the Public Powers of the republic. In addition to this document, Gutiérrez, along with other actors of civil society, organized citizen protests, marches and rallies in front of the National Palace, through a platform called the National Consensus Instance{{Cite news|url=https://nomada.gt/pais/los-13-dias-de-agonia-del-expresidente-serrano-y-sus-diferencias-con-opm/|title=“Cómo fue el Serranazo, el último golpe en Guatemala hace 25 años”|last=Nómada gt|first=Guatemala|date=|work=|access-date=}}. === Presidency of Alfonso Portillo (2000-2004) === In early 2003, then president Alfonso Portillo attacks media calling them “clowns”, and stated they were “at the service of obscure interests”{{Cite news|url=|title=Portillo ataca a la prensa|last=Siglo 21|first=“Portillo ataca a la prensa”|date=|work=|access-date=}} and referred to Dionisio Gutierrez as “the circus owner”. Dionisio Gutierrez issued an answer stating that “the government called conspirator and subversive to any person who speaks the truth about the President”{{Cite news|url=|title=Nos gobiernan tres chiflados|last=Sexto Estado|first=7 de febrero de 2003|date=|work=|access-date=}}. === Jueves Negro (2003) === On July 24, 2003, in the streets of several zones of Guatemala City, the General and former President Efraín Ríos-Montt, in an action that has been described as a "populist ruse"{{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/hemeroteca/jueves-negro-el-ardid-populista-de-efrain-rios-montt|title=Jueves Negro|last=Prensa Libre, 07/24/2003|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}, demanded that the Supreme Electoral Tribunal register him as a presidential candidate, despite being banned for having led a coup d'état. A few days before the event, on July 14 of that year, the Constitutional Court issued a decision denying the petition. For this reason, on Monday, July 21, the General indirectly led his followers to rebellion, and warned that he would not be held responsible if the protests got out of control. On July 24, several people took different points of the city, and one of the most threatened places was the Centro Empresarial building, where the corporate offices of Multi Inversiones is located. One of the most fierce opponents of the inscription of Ríos Montt was Dionisio Gutierrez. According to Prensa Libre:
'''''“That day, the lives of hundreds of employees in that building was put at risk, because several tires were set on fire, which made the air unbreathable, and the mob threatened to burn the building”.'''''
After being besieged for twelve hours, 900 people who had been trapped in the Centro Empresarial building were rescued and the protesters withdrew. The damage to property, life and production was invaluable. ==== Opposition to the government of the UNE (2010) ==== On Thursday, July 1, 2010, the government of then President Álvaro Colom denounced a "destabilization plan composed of attacks on security forces and reports in some media outlets" in the public complaint, the president accused Dionisio Gutiérrez as one of the responsible for that plan. In response, the businessman said "With all due respect, I ask you not to fall into the totalitarian trap".{{Cite news|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/gutierrez-pide-a-colom-evitar-caer-en-tentacion-totalitaria/|title=Gutiérrez pide a Colom evitar caer en tentación totalitaria|last=Siglo 21, 7/05/2010|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} Months later, Dionisio Gutiérrez started one of the most controversial episodes of 2010 due to a comment against President Álvaro Colom and his wife Sandra Torres at the National Entrepreneurs Conference.''El Periódico''. Guatemala, viernes 24 de diciembre de 2010. Página 4. After the incident, Dionisio Gutierrez ended up taking distance from the “Libre Encuentro" program and the country, alleging, among other reasons, the "evident increase in forms of harassment and intimidation, even constant death threats" against him{{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/noticias/justicia/Dionisio-Gutierrez-programa-Libre-Encuentro_0_355764450.html|title=Dionisio Gutiérrez deja el programa Libre Encuentro|last=Prensa Libre|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}. ==Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo== In 2012, already back in Guatemala City, Dionisio Gutiérrez created the Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo (Freedom and Development Foundation), which is an independent, private and proactive think tank dedicated to the study and analysis of social, economic and political issues to promote values and principles of a free society. As president of the Foundation, Gutiérrez leads a team of intellectuals with whom he works in multiple civic activities and develops the articulation of long-term state proposals for Central America.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/somos|title=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|last=Quienes somos|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === Dimensión === On January 27, 2013 was born the television show "Dimension", sponsored by the Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo, which was broadcast weekly on Canal 3, under the direction of Dionisio Gutiérrez until August 2018. The show dealt with social issues and tried to promote participation "to generate reflection on the complex problems that afflict Guatemalan and Central American societies”.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/dimension|title=Dimensión|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === Confrontation with the Partido Patriota Government (2015) === In August 2015, following the announcement of the participation of Vice President Roxana Baldetti and President of the Republic Otto Pérez Molina in a structure dedicated to customs fraud in Guatemala known as La Línea, Dionisio Gutiérrez asks the resignation of the then President Otto Pérez Molina in a Public Letter from the Libertad y Desarrollo Foundation. {{Cite news|url=https://republica.gt/2015/08/24/dionisio-gutierrez-a-perez-molina-general-marchese-usted/|title=Dionisio Gutiérrez a Pérez Molina: “General, márchese usted”|last=República GT, 08/24/2015|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} In an interview in a local media outlet, Dionisio Gutiérrez said about Otto Pérez Molina:
'''''“An individual I met in the Serranazo days, and with whom I no longer had a significant contact until the end of 2010, when he was the most persecuted opposition politician, and I was the most persecuted civil citizen by the government of the UNE party. And four months after he was appointed President, I denounced his would be another government taking Guatemala towards lost paths”.''''' {{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/dionisio-gutierrez-esta-claro-el-lado-correcto-de-la-historia-para-que-el-pais-avance|title=Dionisio Gutiérrez: Está claro el lado correcto de la historia para que Guatemala avance|last=Prensa Libre, 03/05/2018|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}
=== Encuentros Ciudadanos === In September 2016, through the Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo, Dionisio Gutierrez opened the first Encuentros Ciudadano (Citizen Encounters) with a speech focused on inequality in the country. Since then, these meetings have become an annual experience that is replicated in other cities in Guatemala, where key personalities from different sectors of the society get together to discuss about different topics of national interest. In April 2017, the second Encuentro Ciudadano was held, in which the country reality was analyzed, with emphasis in politics, inequality and underdevelopment. On March 7, 2018, the main topic on the third Encuentro Ciudadano focused on the importance of the fight against corruption in Guatemala. {{Cite news|url=http://www.fundacionlibertad.com/seccion/eventos/encuentros-ciudadanos|title=Encuentros Ciudadanos|last=Fundación Libertad y Desarrollo|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}Then Attorney General Thelma Aldana and the Chief of the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG), Iván Velásquez were invited as panelists, the latter participated through a pre-recorded interview. In his keynote, Gutierrez said that president Jimmy Morales had not been invited and encouraged him to “''stop shaming Guatemala''” and to “''stop representing the obscure forces that don’t want the country to change. Your actions contradict your words''”.{{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/politica/el-tercer-encuentro-ciudadano-estado-democratico-o-capturado-lo-preside-dionisio-gutierrez|title=Tercer Encuentro Ciudadano {{!}} Participantes coinciden en que prevalece captura del Estado|last=Prensa Libre, Guatemala|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} === Position regarding CICIG and the fight against corruption === In late February 2018, Gutierrez makes a public appearance, in the days of the formation of the Frente Ciudadano Contra la Corrupción (Citizen Front Against Corruption), formed by businessmen, activists, Mayan authorities, communicators and several personalities from the society, who manifested their commitment in the fight against corruption and impunity in Guatemala, and also their commitment to support the permanence of Iván Velásquez as Chief of the International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG), and the work of Thelma Aldana as Attorney General of the Ministerio Público.{{Cite news|url=https://elperiodico.com.gt/nacion/2018/02/28/diversos-sectores-conforman-frente-ciudadano-contra-la-corrupcion/|title=“Diversos sectores conforman Frente Ciudadano Contra la Corrupción”|last=El periódico, Guatemala|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} The role of Gutierrez at the front of the fight against corruption has earned him several criticism from different sectors.{{Cite news|url=https://elfaro.net/es/201809/centroamerica/22405/Siete-tesis-para-el-desconcierto-de-Guatemala.htm?st-full_text=all&tpl=11|title=Siete tesis para el desconcierto de Guatemala|last=Enrique|first=Naveda|date=|work=|access-date=}} On April 30, 2018, given the smear campaign against CICIG and the lobby that was being made in Washington against the Commission, Dionisio Gutierrez sent a letter to twelve Senators and Congressmen of the United States, about the importance of the permanence of CICIG in Guatemala.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/carta-de-dionisio-gutierrez-a-senadores-y-congresistas-de-estados-unidos/|title=Carta a Senadores y Congresistas de Estados Unidos|last=Dionisiogutiérrez.gt|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} In that letter, Gutierrez lists a number of prosecuted officials by the Guatemalan justice due to corruption. He also stated that CICIG “has demonstrated its ability to bring justice to Guatemala, and for the first time in recent history, let Guatemalans have trust and faith in their government institutions. {{Cite news|url=https://www.guatevision.com/noticias/nacional/empresario-dionisio-gutierrez-envia-carta-a-senadores-de-eeuu-por-cicig/|title=Empresario Dionisio Gutierrez envía carta a senadores de EEUU por CICIG|last=Guatevisión|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} ==Razón de Estado== On September 19, 2018, after three years away from the television, Dionisio Gutierrez makes a comeback to the screen with the show “Razón de Estado”,{{Cite web|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/razon-de-estado/|title=Razón de Estado|last=Dionisiogutierrez.gt|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} broadcast through Guatevisión channel, on Wednesdays at 9:30 PM. According to the show’s website, “it is a tribune for debate and reflection, engaged with freedom, democracy, and rule of law”.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dionisiogutierrez.gt/television/|title=Razón de Estado|last=Dionisio Gutiérrez|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Several content formats are used in this show: documentaries, interviews, discussion panels, and coverages. ==Awards, acknowledgments and relevant positions== In 2012, the Power Awards and the American Business Council Foundation of the United States{{Cite news|url=http://www.estrategiaynegocios.net/empresasymanagement/empresas/460363-330/poder-awards-reconoce-al-dr-dionisio-gutierrez|title=Poder Awards reconoce al Dr. Dionisio Gutiérrez|last=Estrategia y Negocios|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} recognized the efforts and trajectory of Gutiérrez by bestowing upon him the award “Empowering Democracy".{{Cite news|url=http://www.exteriores.gob.es/Embajadas/GUATEMALA/es/Embajada/Documents/boletin%20n%C2%BA%2024.pdf|title=El Embajador impone la condecoraciones a Dionisio Gutiérrez y a la Hermana Uti|last=Exteriorres.gob.es|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} In 2014, His Majesty, King Felipe VI of Spain, awarded him the high honor of the Order of Civil Merit in Commendation to Gutiérrez. He is also a founder and trustee of the School of Government in Guatemala, {{Cite web|url=https://edg.org.gt/|title=Escuela de Gobierno|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} an educational entity whose mission is to transform the way government and politics are conducted in Guatemala. == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Gutierrez Mayorga, Dionisio}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Guatemalan businesspeople]] [[Category:People associated with the Universidad Francisco Marroquín]] [[Category:University of Salamanca alumni]]

[[File:Intel Board of Directors.jpg|thumb|320x320px|Intel Board of Directors]] A '''director''' is a person from a group of managers who leads or supervises a particular area of a company<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/director.html|title=What is director? definition and meaning|website=BusinessDictionary.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}}</ref>. [[corporation|Companies]] that use this term often have many directors spread throughout different business functions or roles (e.g. director of [[human resources]]).<ref name="about.com Human Resources">{{cite web |author=Heathfield, Susan M |url=http://humanresources.about.com/od/jobdescriptions/a/HR_Director.htm |title=Sample Human Resources Director Job Description |publisher=about.com}}</ref> The director usually reports directly to a [[vice president]] or to the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] directly in order to let them know the progress of the organization. Large organizations also sometimes have assistant directors or deputy directors. ''Director'' commonly refers to the lowest level of executive in an organization, but many large companies use the title of ''associate director'' more frequently. Some companies also have regional directors and area directors. Regional directors are present in companies that are organized by location and have their departments under that. They are responsible for the operations for their particular country. Though directors are the first stage in the executive team, area directors are seen as higher up, based on their area of control.
==Corporate titles== {{Main|Corporate title}} Corporate titles (commonly known as business titles) are titles given to individuals within a business depending on the role they have and which also portray the duties and responsibilities within that specific role. The larger the business, the more titles that are present, such as CEO, COO and executive directors.
Those that have higher roles within a company such as the elite positions are often referred to as "chief" and those that have lower roles within the company are employees that simply carry out day-to-day tasks. There are many titles within a company such as executive director, managing director, company director and chairman.
The corporate structure consists of four key areas: * Board of directors- oversees a department and maintains full operational responsibilities area is next to the C-level executives in the corporate jobs hierarchy. They oversee daily tasks of the business or the company. * Employees- This role is ranked at the bottom of the structure. Employees work on daily tasks and objectives either in a group or individually aiming for that common goal.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.hierarchystructure.com/corporate-jobs-hierarchy/|title = Corporate titles|date = 2014-10-22| accessdate = 2014-10-22|website = Corporate jobs hierarchy|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Structuring a board of directors == Depending upon the size of an organization or a company, the number of directors can vary. Start-up companies can have a single director, which is the minimum for a private limited company according to the law. However, as organizations and businesses expand, the number of directors can increase because more tasks and responsibilities become present. For example, if the company expands and has more than one department, such as finance, sales, marketing, production and IT, then the business may form a board of directors, with each director overseeing a department and maintaining full responsibility within that department.
A board of directors ensures that a clearly outlined structure is in place which will help the business to work much more efficiently.
Larger businesses and organizations will form a clear board structure as the following:
'''Chairman''' - This particular role within the company is often a non executive role that also has the task of overseeing the entire business or organization.
'''Managing Director''' - A managing director is employed by the business, often by the chairman. Other roles include running the business and producing salaries. The managing director manages the board of directors and oversees the performance of the business, thus reporting back to the chairman.
'''Executive Directors''' - A group of executive directors who each play a significant role within the company. They maintain full responsibility over their respective departments such as Finance, Marketing and Sales. Each director manages their department ensuring that tasks and objectives are being met. Executive directors also sit on the board.
'''Non-executive directors''' - These advise the business by proposing different forms of strategy and also decide remuneration of the executive directors.
Having a clear structure within the business has a positive impact on the employees and it also helps to organize the business. By having a team of executive directors, employees can report to their executive directors if a problem or an issue occurs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nibusinessinfo.co.uk/content/structuring-board-directors|title = Structuring a board of directors|date = 2014-10-22|accessdate = 2014-10-22|website = https://www.nibusinessinfo.co.uk/content/structuring-board-directors|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Managing director== {{Main|Chief executive officer}} A managing director oversees the performance of the company as a whole and then has the duty to report back to the chairman or board of directors. The chairman or board of directors may set daily and weekly targets, which should be met by the employees that are working within their respective departments. The managing director also has the role to report their progress so the board can evaluate it to see if targets have been achieved.<ref>{{cite web|title=Role of the managing director|url=http://www.iod.com/guidance/briefings/cgbis-the-role-of-the-managing-director|website=IOD|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref>
===Roles include=== * Maintaining the overall performance of the company and in particular the departments within. * Producing and planning strategic operating plans and objectives for the long-term future. Also ensuring all short term targets have been achieved. * Keeping in regular contact with the board of directors or chairman and to maintain a positive relationship.
== Executive director == {{Main|Executive director}} An executive director within a company or an organization is usually from the board of directors and oversees a specific department within the organization such as Marketing, Finance, Production and IT. The Executive Director must ensure that all employees within his/her department are achieving the objectives which have been set and must also make daily decisions within the department.<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Director definition|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/executive+director|website=The free dictionary|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref>
===Roles include=== * Overseeing their specific department such as Finance, Marketing or Manufacturing. * Maintaining the role of a specified decision maker within the department. * Analyzing and evaluating the efficiency of day to day tasks within the departments and ensuring all objectives are being met.<ref>{{cite web|title=getting the right people|url=http://hrcouncil.ca/hr-toolkit/right-people-job-descriptions-executive-director.cfm|website=hrcouncil.ca|accessdate=20 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/running-a-limited-company|title = Role of a director|date = 2014-10-20|accessdate = |website = GOV.UK|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Company director == {{Main|Board of directors}} {{Confusing section|date=October 2018}} A company director is one of the employees within a group of managers who maintains a prolific role within an organization and usually has the higher role within an organization. This is mainly because they decide on how to control the business and also make the final and key decisions.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/business-english/company-director|title = Company Director definition|date = 2014-10-20|accessdate = |website = Cambridge.org|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
=== Roles include === The company director(s) is mainly responsible for: * Ensuring the company’s '''strategic objectives''' '''and plans''' which have been set are being met. * '''Analyzing and monitoring''' the progress of its employees towards achieving the objectives and targets set. * '''Appointing or hiring senior managers''' for certain departments such as Finance and Marketing.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.iod.com/guidance/briefings/cgbis-directors-duties-and-responsibilities|title = directors duties and responsibilities.|date = |accessdate = 2014-10-20|website = IOD|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/running-a-limited-company|title = Running a limited company|date = |accessdate = 2014-10-20|website = GOV.UK|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Finance director == {{Main|Chief financial officer}} A finance director oversees and maintains full responsibility of the business's finance department. He/she is also responsible in ensuring that the chief executive and the board receive the flow of the financial information. Other responsibilities include producing annual accounts, maintaining control of complete transactions, setting out financial targets and budgets for the business and also managing the companies policies. The finance director must also report to the managing director.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.iod.com/guidance/briefings/cgbis-the-role-of-the-finance-director|title = The role of the Finance Director|date = 2014-10-22|accessdate = 2014-10-22|website = http://www.iod.com/guidance/briefings/cgbis-the-role-of-the-finance-director|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Dirk van de Put | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |57|2017|08|02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20170802/NEWS07/170809945/who-is-dirk-van-de-put-the-new-ceo-of-mondelez|title=Who is Dirk Van de Put, the new CEO of Mondelez?|publisher=|accessdate=8 January 2018}} | birth_place = [[Mechelen]], Belgium | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = Belgian | citizenship = Belgian and US | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Ghent University]]
[[University of Antwerp]] | occupation = Businessman | title = Chairman and CEO, [[Mondelez International]] | term = November 2017- | predecessor = [[Irene Rosenfeld]] | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relations = | website = }} '''Dirk van de Put''' (born 1959/60) is a Belgian businessman, and the chairman and chief executive officer (CEO) of [[Mondelez International]], since November 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/01/mondelez.html|title=Dirk Van de Put named CEO of Mondelēz as long-time CEO Irene Rosenfeld retires|first=|last=CNBC|date=2 August 2017|website=cnbc.com|accessdate=4 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mondelez-ceo-idUSKBN1AI1DY|title=Outsider replaces long-time CEO at Oreo cookie maker Mondelez|author=|date=2 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=4 August 2017|via=Reuters}} He also became chairman in April 2018. ==Early life== Van de Put is a native of [[Mechelen]], Belgium, and has a veterinary medicine degree from [[Ghent University]], and a master's degree in business from the [[University of Antwerp]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20170802/NEWS07/170809945/who-is-dirk-van-de-put-the-new-ceo-of-mondelez|title=Who is Dirk Van de Put, the new CEO of Mondelez?|author=|date=|website=chicagobusiness.com|accessdate=4 August 2017}} He is fluent in Dutch, English, French, Spanish, and Portuguese.{{fact|date=June 2018}} ==Career== Van de Put worked for [[Coca-Cola]], [[Mars Inc]], [[Novartis]] and [[Groupe Danone]], before becoming CEO of the Canadian frozen foods manufacturer [[McCain Foods]] in 2010. He is a non-executive director of [[Mattel]]. In November 2017, he succeeded [[Irene Rosenfeld]] as CEO of [[Mondelez International]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/01/mondelez.html|title=Dirk Van de Put named CEO of Mondelēz as long-time CEO Irene Rosenfeld retires|first=|last=CNBC|date=2 August 2017|website=cnbc.com|accessdate=4 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mondelez-ceo-idUSKBN1AI1DY|title=Outsider replaces long-time CEO at Oreo cookie maker Mondelez|author=|date=2 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=4 August 2017|via=Reuters}} He also became chairman in April 2018. ==Personal life== Van de Put has Belgian and US citizenship. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:van de Put, Dirk}} [[Category:Belgian businesspeople]] [[Category:Belgian chief executives]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ghent University alumni]] [[Category:University of Antwerp alumni]] [[Category:People from Mechelen]]

{{Infobox settlement |name=Downtown San Antonio |settlement_type=[[Neighborhoods and districts of San Antonio|District]] of [[San Antonio]] |image_skyline=Downtown-san-antonio.jpeg |image_caption=The skyline from the metropolitan area's tallest skyscraper, the [[Tower of the Americas]] |image_blank_emblem= File:Downtown San Antonio logo.jpg |blank_emblem_size=200px |blank_emblem_type=The Downtown Brand Mark, launched in 2016, visually represents the interconnected nature of the neighborhoods, people, cultures, and lifestyles that make up the fabric of downtown. |blank_emblem_alt=The Downtown Brand Mark, launched in 2016, visually represents the interconnected nature of the neighborhoods, people, cultures, and lifestyles that make up the fabric of downtown. }} [[File:San Antonio - Texas Flag.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Texas Flag in San Antonio]] '''Downtown San Antonio''' is the [[central business district]] of [[San Antonio, Texas]], [[United States]]. It also serves as the urban core of [[Greater San Antonio]], a metropolitan area with nearly 2.5 million people. In addition to being encircled by Loops [[Texas State Highway Loop 1604|1604]] and [[Interstate 410|410]], Downtown San Antonio is encircled by three Interstate [[freeway]]s: [[Interstate 35 in Texas|I-35]], [[Interstate 37 (Texas)|I-37]], and [[Interstate 10 in Texas|I-10]]. Together, the three highways create a rectangular route around the city's urban core: I-35 to the north and west, I-37 to the east, and I-10 to the south. The rectangular loop has a nine-mile circumference and is known as the "Downtown Loop" or "Central Loop", which encompasses both it and [[Neighborhoods and districts of San Antonio#South Side|Southtown]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} ==Districts== Downtown is home to many districts including the Alamo District, Alamodome District, Central Business District, Convention Center District, Historic Civic District, Houston Street District, Lavaca District, [[La Villita]] District, Market Square District, North Downtown, River North District, Zona cultural, San Antonio CO-OP district, River Bend District, [[King William Historic District]], South Flores Warehouse District, SoSo (South of Southtown), [[Southtown Arts District]], Eastbourough, and the University District.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} The northwestern corner of Downtown is the Medical District. The Central Business District is home to the [[Rivercenter]], anchored by a [[Macy's]], an [[IMAX]] theater, an [[H&M]], and formerly [[Dillard's]]. The five-level [[Art Deco]] Dillard's, at the corner of Alamo and Commerce streets, opened in 1887 as [[Joske's]]. Joske's flagship store was {{convert|551000|sqft|m2|-2}} in floor space until Dillard's bought the Joske's chain in 1987. In August 2008, Dillard's moved out of the historic building as a part of a redevelopment plan for Rivercenter Mall.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} The Rivercenter Mall was built around [[St. Joseph Catholic Church (San Antonio, Texas)|St. Joseph Catholic Church]] after the church refused to move. Many people travel to visit the Alamo Plaza Historic District, which houses the famous Alamo. Attractions such as the river walk are home to many of the festivities throughout the year including [http://www.niosa.org/ NIOSA] [[A Night in Old San Antonio]] which celebrates Fiesta, Cinco de Mayo, and numerous parades such as celebrations for their home NBA team the Spurs, Christmas parades and much more.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} In the southeastern part of Downtown is the [[Alamodome]], a 65,000-seat arena that hosts many types of events, primarily conventions and football games. While many companies based in San Antonio are based in other parts of the city, particularly the Northwest Side and Uptown, there are companies based in Downtown San Antonio, such as [[H-E-B]], [[Eye Care Centers of America]], [[Bromley Originate Change]], and [[Kell Muñoz Architects]]. ==Government and infrastructure== [[File:Bexar County Courthouse, San Antonio (2006).jpg|thumb|right|[[Bexar County Courthouse]]]] The [[San Antonio Police Department]] (SAPD) serves Downtown from the Central Substation."[http://www.sanantonio.gov/sapd/subsmap.asp?res=1280&ver=true Map of San Antonio Police Service Areas]." City of San Antonio. Retrieved on March 29, 2010. The main SAPD headquarters are in Downtown."[http://www.sanantonio.gov/sapd/contact.asp Contacting SAPD]." City of San Antonio. Retrieved on March 29, 2010. The [[San Antonio Fire Department]] (SAFD), the city's fire protection and EMS service, is also based in Downtown. The [[Texas Courts of Appeals|Texas Fourth Court of Appeals]] is located in the Cadena-Reeves Justice Center in Downtown San Antonio."[http://www.4thcoa.courts.state.tx.us/court/contact.asp Contact Information]." Texas Fourth Court of Appeals. Retrieved on March 9, 2010. The San Antonio Post Office and Courthouse, located at 615 East Houston Street, functions as a [[United States Postal Service]] post office and as a regional office for federal agencies."[https://archive.is/20130209060133/http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/72978?p=1&s=TX&service_name=post_office&z=San+Antonio Post Office Location - DOWNTOWN SAN ANTONIO]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on April 16, 2009. In 2009, $61 million were allocated to renovate the Post Office and Courthouse as a part of federal stimulus spending.Contreras, Guillermo". $61 million to upgrade downtown post office". http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/61_million_to_upgrade_downtown_post_office.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422173721/http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local_news/61_million_to_upgrade_downtown_post_office.html |date=2009-04-22 }}. Retrieved 4/21/2009. The six story, [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]], [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] building opened in 1937."[http://www.gsa.gov/Portal/gsa/ep/contentView.do?contentType=GSA_BASIC&contentId=14898 San Antonio U.S. Post Office and Courthouse] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509134725/http://www.gsa.gov/Portal/gsa/ep/contentView.do?contentType=GSA_BASIC&contentId=14898 |date=May 9, 2009 }}." ''[[U.S. General Services Administration]]''. Retrieved on April 16, 2009. ==Diplomatic missions== [[File:Mexican Consulate General San Antonio.jpg|thumb|[[Diplomatic missions of Mexico|Consulate-General of Mexico in San Antonio]]]] The [[Diplomatic missions of Mexico|Consulate-General of Mexico in San Antonio]] is located at 127 Navarro Street in Downtown.[http://portal.sre.gob.mx/sanantonio/ Home page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221182813/http://portal.sre.gob.mx/sanantonio/ |date=February 21, 2009 }}. ''[[Diplomatic missions of Mexico|Consulate-General of Mexico in San Antonio]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. ==Transportation== [[Greyhound Lines]] operates the San Antonio Station at 500 North St. Marys Street."[http://www.greyhound.com/home/TicketCenter/en/terminal.asp?city=682561 San Antonio, TX] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122225921/http://www.greyhound.com/home/TicketCenter/en/terminal.asp?city=682561 |date=November 22, 2008 }}." ''[[Greyhound Lines]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. [[VIA Metropolitan Transit]] operates an Information Center at 211 W. Commerce Street, its Main Executive Office, called The Grand, at 123 N. Medina Street, Ellis Alley Park & Ride, and Centro Plaza, the company's main transit facility, which is located across from the Grand. Both Centro Plaza and The Grand are located in the Cattleman Square District of Downtown. Amtrak operates a train station in St. Paul's Square. Since Downtown is located at the City's geographical center, Interstate Highways 10, 35, and 37 combine to form a Downtown Circulator, which completely surrounds Downtown San Antonio. IH35 borders Downtown S.A. to the north and west, IH10 to the south and west (overlaps with IH35), and IH37 along the east end. ==Education== ===Primary and secondary schools=== Downtown is within the [[San Antonio Independent School District]], which is headquartered in there."[http://www.saisd.net/main/index.php?option=com_contact&view=contact&id=1&Itemid=16 Contact Us]." [[San Antonio Independent School District]]. Retrieved on March 28, 2010. Austin Academy, a PreK-8 school, is northwest of Downtown and serves parts of northern Downtown."[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=3&Itemid=5 Austin Academy Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. Bonham Elementary School, an elementary school which will become PreK-8 by 2009, is south of Downtown and serves southern Downtown."[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=31&Itemid=5 Bonham Elementary Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. Bowden Elementary School, east of Downtown, serves parts of northern Downtown."[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=32&Itemid=5 Bowden Elementary Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. Middle schools serving sections of Downtown include Tafolla,"[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=24&Itemid=5 Tafolla Middle School Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. Twain,"[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=cat_view&gid=8&dir=DESC&order=name&Itemid=5&limit=5&limitstart=0 Twain Middle School Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. and Wheatley."[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=26&Itemid=5 Wheatley Middle School Attendance Boundary]." ''[[San Antonio Independent School District]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. Northern Downtown is in the attendance zone of [[Fox Tech High School]] in Downtown,"[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=8&Itemid=5 Fox Tech High School Attendance Boundary]." [[San Antonio Independent School District]]. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. while southern parts are zoned to [[Brackenridge High School]], south of Downtown."[http://www.saisd.net/dept/facilitiesservices/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=5&Itemid=5 Brackenridge High School Attendance Boundary]." [[San Antonio Independent School District]]. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. [[Navarro High School]], a magnet school, is adjacent to Downtown."[http://www.saisd.net/schools/navarro014/ Navarro High School]." [[San Antonio Independent School District]]. Retrieved on March 28, 2010. ===Colleges and universities=== [[File:UTSA Downtown.jpg|thumb|right|[[University of Texas at San Antonio]]'s downtown campus]] [[File:Trinity University (Texas).jpg|thumb|right| The main entrance to [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]]. Also pictured are the iconic Murchison Tower and Northrup Hall.]] The [[University of Texas at San Antonio]] has both its Downtown and HemisFair Park campuses in the downtown area. [[Trinity University (Texas)|Trinity University]] is a private, primarily undergraduate, liberal arts college in midtown San Antonio, approximately five miles due north of downtown. ===Public libraries=== The six-story Central Library, a branch of the [[San Antonio Public Library]] (SAPL) system, is located at 600 Soledad Street."[http://www.mysapl.org/location.aspx?id=cen Central Library]." ''[[San Antonio Public Library]]''. Retrieved on May 4, 2009. SAPL also operates a library portal located at the Briscoe Western Art Museum on Market Street.{{cite web |url= https://www.briscoemuseum.org/visit-the-briscoe/san-antonio-public-library-portal |title= San Antonio Public Library Portal |website= Briscoe Western Art Museum |access-date= May 20, 2018}} [[BiblioTech (Bexar County)|BiblioTech]] digital public library has a satellite branch at the [[Bexar County Courthouse]] in the Central Jury Room.{{cite news |last= Moravec |first= Eva Ruth |title= New digital library opens at Bexar County Courthouse |newspaper= [[San Antonio Express-News]] |date= January 16, 2014 |url= https://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/New-digital-library-opens-at-Bexar-County-5146049.php |access-date= May 20, 2018}} ==Attractions== The [[Alamo Mission in San Antonio]] ("the Alamo"), located in Downtown, is Texas' top tourist attraction. Because of the mission, San Antonio is often called the "Alamo City".{{cite web|last1=Popik|first1=Barry|title=Alamo City (San Antonio nickname)|url=http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/alamo_city_san_antonio_nickname|website=The Big Apple|date=December 20, 2007}} The [[San Antonio River Walk|River Walk]], which meanders through the Downtown area, is the city's second-most-visited attraction.{{cite web|title=Destination SA Update 2011|url=http://www.sanantoniotourism.com/downloads/research/DestinationSAReport.pdf|website=San Antonio Area Tourism Council|publisher=San Antonio Area Tourism Council|format=Report|date=March 2012}} It was one of the first restorations of an urban river.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} Lined with numerous shops, bars, and restaurants, as well as the [[Arneson River Theater]], this attraction is transformed into an impressive festival of lights during the Christmas and New Year holiday period, and is suffused with the local sounds of [[Baile Folklorico|folklorico]] and [[flamenco]] music during the summer, particularly during celebrations such as the [[Fiesta Noche del Rio]]. Also based along the River Walk is the newly restored [[Aztec On The River]], the only surviving exotic-themed [[movie palace]] in Texas.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} The Downtown Area also features [[Cathedral of San Fernando]], [[The Majestic Theatre, San Antonio|The Majestic Theatre]], [[HemisFair '68|HemisFair]] Park (home of the [[Tower of the Americas]], and UTSA's [[Institute of Texan Cultures]]), [[Pearl Brewing Company|Pearl]], [[La Villita]], [[Market Square (San Antonio)|Market Square]], the [[Spanish Governor's Palace]], and the historic [[Menger Hotel]]. On the northern side of the Alamo complex, beside the Emily Morgan Hotel, is the San Antonio Cavalry Museum, which features cavalry artifacts and exhibits and is frequented by local re-enactors. The [[Fairmount Hotel (San Antonio, Texas)|Fairmount Hotel]], built in 1906 and San Antonio's second oldest hotel, is in the ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as one of the heaviest buildings ever moved intact. It was placed in its new location, three blocks south of the Alamo, over four days in 1985, and cost $650,000 to move. Not far from the city center there are many local theaters like the overtime theatre. Downtown San Antonio is seeing an uptick of outdoor tourism attractions. With the opening of the Mission Reach section of the River Walk,http://www.sanantonioriver.org/mission_reach/mission_reach.php new recreational tourism businesses such as Mission Bike Tour and Mission Kayak http://www.missionkayak.comhttp://www.missionbiketour.com opened up to give tourists a new visiting experience. Visitors can now do activities such as kayaking the San Antonio river and bicycling to the World Heritage Missions.http://www.texashighways.com/travel/item/7765-mission-kayakhttp://www.southernliving.com/travel/river-walk-san-antoniohttp://www.texasmonthly.com/travel/trip-guide-san-antonio-missions/ ==Gallery==

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}}
[[Image:Enos Kagaba.jpg|thumb|right|Enos Kagaba]]
'''Enos Kagaba''' is a [[Rwanda]]n businessman who, in 2001, was arrested at the [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport]] when he attempted to gain entry into the United States.<ref name="Schaack">Beth Van Schaack & Ronald C. Slye, International Criminal Law and Its Enforcement: Cases and Materials (2007)</ref>
==Arrest== He was initially charged with fraud and attempting to enter the country under false identity. Once the [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|Immigration and Customs Enforcement's Human Rights Violators and Public Safety Unit]] (HRVPSU) became aware that Rwanda had issued an international arrest warrant against Kagaba for actions of genocide during the 1994 war in Rwanda, [[Rwandan Genocide|genocide]] charges were also added.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ice.gov/pi/news/insideice/articles/InsideICE_101204_Web2.htm |title=INSIDE ICE Newsletter: Volume 1, Issue 13: ICE WINS LANDMARK RWANDAN GENOCIDE CASE |accessdate=2008-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080923102422/http://www.ice.gov/pi/news/insideice/articles/insideice_101204_Web2.htm |archivedate=September 23, 2008 }}</ref> A removal order was then issued.
This was the first incidence in the United States of a removal order for the accusation of [[genocide]]. The United States used [[18 U.S.C. §2340a]] to establish jurisdiction over Kagaba.<ref name="Schaack"/> This statute granted jurisdiction over an alleged offender if he: a) is a national of the United States OR b) is present in the United States (regardless of whether he or the victims(s) are/were U.S. nationals).

page.title: Environmental impact of the chemical industry in Sarnia

revision.text:
[[File:Chemical Valley by a Park.jpg|thumb|right|Chemical Valley shown adjoining Rainbow Park]] [[Sarnia]]'s Chemical Valley and the surrounding area are home to sixty-two facilities and refineries. A widely quoted 2007 [[Ecojustice Canada]] report showed those large industrial facilities located within 25 km of Sarnia, Ontario, Canada emitted more than 131,000 tonnes of [[air pollution]] in 2005, a toxic load of more than 1,800 kilograms per resident.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecojustice.ca/publications/reports/report-exposing-canadas-chemical-valley/attachment |title=Exposing Canada’s Chemical Valley-An Investigation of Cumulative Air Pollution Emissions in the Sarnia, Ontario Area |date=October 2007 |publisher= Ecojustice Canada |author1=Elaine MacDonald |author2=Sarah Rang |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref>
==Particulate Matter== [[File:Aajimwnaang Resource Centre right next to Dow Chemical in Chemical Valley.jpg|thumb|right|Aamjiwnaang Resource Centre adjoining [[Dow Chemical]] in Chemical Valley, specifically [[INEOS]] Styrolution (formerly Nova)]] In January 2011, the ''[[Sarnia Observer]]'' noted "Sarnia had by far the highest levels of fine [[particulate matter]] recorded at any of the province's 40 monitoring stations, with significantly [[soot]]ier air than [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]], [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], and [[Chatham, Ontario|Chatham]]".<ref name="Shawn Jeffords">{{cite web |url=http://www.cleanairalliance.org/node/933 |title=Sarnia’s Dirty Air Clouds New Report Touting Air Pollution Cuts |publisher=Sarnia Observer |author=Shawn Jeffords |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> In September 2011, the [[World Health Organization]] reported that "While Canada ranks third in the world when it comes to [[air quality]], Sarnia was ranked the worst city in the country, with the most particulate matter per cubic metre of air."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theobserver.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3312431 |title=Sarnia Air Canada's Worst |publisher=[[Sarnia Observer]] |date=27 September 2011 |author=Tara Jeffrey |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> [[Pamela Calvert]]'s 2006 documentary on the [[Aamjiwnaang First Nation]], ''The Beloved Community'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsreel.org/guides/belovedcommunity/bcdiscuss.htm |title=The Beloved Community |publisher=California Newsreel |author=Pamela Calvert |year=2007 |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> details the startling revelation that the Aamjiwmnaang birth rate of males to females is 1 to 2, the lowest live male birth rate in Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/aboriginals/health.html |title=Aboriginal Canadians, Chemical valley |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |author=Mary Ann Colihan |date=1 April 2008 |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.elc.uvic.ca/associates/documents/ChemicalValleyAssociatesBackgrounder_June13.11.pdf |title=Environmental Rights--Human Rights and Pollution in Sarnia's Chemical Valley |publisher=University of victoria |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> In addition to the detrimental effect on birth rates among the First Nation peoples of the area, there is also correlation between Sarnia and [[cancer rate]]s among men—34% higher overall cancer rate than the provincial average, a [[lung cancer]] rate that is 50% higher, a [[mesothelioma]] rate five times higher and an [[asbestosis]] rate nine times higher.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/dying-for-a-living/article789982/ |title=Dying For a Living |author=Martin Mittelstaedt |publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=3 April 2009|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref>
On a positive note, however, the ''Observer'' also stated in the January 2011 article that, "despite having what has been described as the 'dirtiest air in the province,' Sarnia has reduced its [[nitrogen dioxide]], [[carbon monoxide]] and [[sulfur dioxide]] problems by 30% in the last three years" and "Environment Minister [[John Wilkinson (Canadian politician)|John Wilkinson]] said it's the first time in the report's 39-year history pollutants have not exceeded provincial monitoring standards. That translated into a record low of three [[smog]] advisories and five smog days in 2009."<ref name="Shawn Jeffords"/>
Additionally, a [[Lambton County]] document indicates that in 2005, up to fifty-five percent of [[ground level ozone]] and fine particulate matter emissions come from neighboring US facilities. In fact, the 2005 study "Transboundary Air Pollution in Ontario" states that "Long-range transport and transboundary flow of air pollutants play a significant role in air quality considerations on a regional scale."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ene.gov.on.ca/stdprodconsume/groups/lr/@ene/@resources/documents/resource/std01_079137.pdf |title=Transboundary Air Pollution in Ontario |author1=David Yap |author2=Neville Reid |author3=Gary De Brou |author4=Robert Bloxam |publisher=Ontario Ministry of the Environment |date=June 2005 |accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Imperial Oil Refinery.jpg|thumb|left|Imperial Oil Refinery]] [[File:Esso Holding Tanks.jpg|thumb|right|[[Esso]] holding tanks which are part of the [[Imperial Oil Refinery]]]]
==Water Pollution== [[Water pollution]] is a serious concern in Sarnia. A June 2003 [[Ryerson University]] study concluded that the main source of water pollution in the [[St. Clair River]] occurs at the Sarnia Water Pollution Control Center (WPCC) due to [[chemical spill]]s and [[Environmental impact of shipping|ship emissions]]. The study goes on to say that "A significant reduction of the pollution to the St. Clair River will only be achieved by improving the quality of the Sarnia WPCC effluent."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.civil.ryerson.ca/urban/techno/stormwater/studies/6-0-3.htm |title=Pollution Prevention and Control Planning Study |publisher=Ryerson University |date=June 2003 |accessdate=7 April 2012}}</ref> In 2008, the city resolved to replace the aging sewer pumps that controlled the effluent. Minutes of a meeting between Mayor [[Mike Bradley (politician)|Mike Bradley]] and Sarnia City Council state "The cost of repairing the raw sewage pumps is a significant portion of purchasing a new unit. However based on the performance of the existing units over the past 8 years, City staff prefers to look at other manufacturers for replacing the existing [[Fairbanks-Morse]] pumps as they require their second rebuilding."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sarnia.civicweb.net/FileStorage/514300623A90480D801412C659F39B33-Water%20Pollution%20Control%20Centre%20rpt.pdf |title=Mayor Bradley and Members of Sarnia City Council Water Pollution Control Centre – Raw Sewage Pump Replacement |publisher=City of Sarnia |date=14 October 2008 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> In 2010, though, the Water Distribution Report indicated that "It should be noted that no filter effluent turbidity exceeded the prescribed test result for adverse reporting..."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.city.sarnia.on.ca/pdf/2010%20Water%20Distribution%20Report%20-%20LAWSS.pdf |title=2010 Water Distribution Report |publisher=City of Sarnia |date=August 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> Further, the Water Distribution Report concluded that "Note- No inorganic or organic parameters exceeded half the standard prescribed in Schedule 2 of the Ontario Drinking Water Quality Standards."
==Plans for Pollution Improvement== As a city, Sarnia is committed to the improvement of its pollution, both air and water. The following statements from City of Sarnia Website succinctly establish this position: "As part of the City's commitment to monitoring and improving the environment, the City Council has established a number of committees to advise Council as well as appointing City representatives to outside committees who have an interest in the environment and the preservation of habitats" and "The City of Sarnia has adopted a Smog Alert Response Plan in support of the Ontario Government's [[Air Quality Ontario]] initiative. The initiative is to provide better and more timely air quality information to the Ontario public. City staff are notified of smog alerts and implement the air quality improvement strategies outlined in the City's Smog Alert Plan.".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.city.sarnia.on.ca/visit.asp?sectionid=220 |title=City of Sarnia Environmental Services |publisher=City of Sarnia |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2012}}</ref> In 2009, Sarnia had a record low three smog advisories and only five smog days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleanairalliance.org/node/933 |author=Shawn Jeffords |title=Sarnia's Dirty Air Clouds New Report of Pollution Cuts |publisher=The Sarnia Observer |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref> The County of Lambton reports that from 1995–2008, Sarnia experienced a high of thirteen smog advisories and forty-six smog days, both in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lambtonhealth.on.ca/environmental/air/#advisories_to_date |title=County of Lambton, Sarnia-Lambton Smog Advisories to date |publisher=County of Lambton |year=2011 |accessdate=17 April 2012}}</ref>
==Shale Gas Controversy== Despite all Sarnia has done to improve its pollution, there are plans to bring [[shale gas]] into Chemical Valley by pipeline in mid-2013. This process is environmentally divisive because it necessitates [[hydraulic fracturing]] to extract the gas. Hydraulic fracturing involves injecting a liquid into rock, shale or otherwise, at very high pressure to extract [[fossil fuels]] such as the aforementioned [[shale gas]]. Environmentalists oppose hydraulic fracturing since it can damage water supplies and produce long lasting toxic deposits, either in the waste water produced, air particulates, or solid forms of the gels or chemicals mixed with the water as part of the process. Supporters tout the employment benefits to an already sagging [[Sarnia]] [[petrochemical industry]]. Business interests seem to have won the argument since the shale gas is expected to flow into Chemical Valley this year, notably to [[Nova Chemicals]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theobserver.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=3132207 |title=Industry Abuzz Over Shale Gas |publisher=The Sarnia Observer |author=Shawn Jeffords |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=https://lfpress.com/news/london/2012/03/16/19511336.html |title=Switch to U.S. Shale Gas a Boon for Sarnia Lobs, CHEMICAL VALLEY: NOVA EXPANDING OPERATIONS |publisher=The London Free Press |author=Tyler Kula |date=16 March 2012 |accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> <ref> {{cite journal | url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/blogs/greeninc/Howarth2011.pdf | title=Methane and the greenhouse-gas footprint of natural gas from shale formations|author1=Howarth, Robert W. |author2=Santoro, Renee |author3=Ingraffea |publisher=Climatic Change (open access via Springerlink) |date=13 March 2012}}</ref> <ref> {{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/338505/title/Natural_gas_wells_leakier_than_believed | title=Natural gas wells leakier than believed. Measurements at Colorado site show methane release higher than previous estimates | author=Powell, Devin |publisher=[[Science News]] Magazine for the Society of Science and the Public | date=24 March 2012 |volume=181 |issue=6 |page=16}}</ref> <ref> {{cite web |url=http://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2011/12/08/epa-blames-fracking-for-wyoming-groundwater-contamination/ |title=EPA Blames Fracking for Wyoming Groundwater Contamination |author=Susan Phillips |date=8 December 2011 |work=StateImpact Pennsylvania |publisher=WITF, WHYY & NPR |accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref> <ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=shale-gas-and-hydraulic-fracturing |title=What the Frack? Natural Gas from Subterranean Shale Promises U.S. Energy Independence--With Environmental Costs |author=David Biello |date=30 March 2010 |work=[[Scientific American]] |accessdate=18 April 2012}}</ref>
==Warning Sirens== Due to the risk of hazardous materials incidents (chemical emergencies) occurring in the industrial corridor south of Sarnia, four [[Siren (noisemaker)|sirens]] have been placed in Sarnia south of Wellington Street, three more on nearby the [[Aamjiwnaang First Nation]] reserve, three in [[Corunna, Ontario|Corunna]], and one in [[Point Edward, Ontario|Point Edward]].<ref>[http://www.caer.ca/PDF%20Files/Home%20Emergency%20Preparedness%20Guide%20-%20Final.pdf CAER's Home Emergency Preparedness Guide] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315182436/http://www.caer.ca/PDF%20Files/Home%20Emergency%20Preparedness%20Guide%20-%20Final.pdf |date=2012-03-15 }}</ref> In the event of an emergency requiring immediate action by the public, the sirens are sounded for a three-minute period, serving as an alert to the public to [[Shelter in place|seek shelter indoors]] and to tune to a [[#Radio|local radio station]] for updated instructions. These sirens are tested (and can be heard) every Monday at 12:30pm to ensure proper functioning. An emergency Command Centre located at the Sarnia Police Station can coordinate deployments of emergency responders during hazardous materials incidents.<ref>[http://www.caer.ca/warning.html CAER Community Warning System] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907233642/http://www.caer.ca/warning.html |date=September 7, 2013 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
